titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
The snow continued, with little intermission, through the last night, and this day— I rode, not without difficulty, to the second Presbyterian Church, on New York Avenue— Where were assembled, the present Minister, Mr. Matthew Hale. Smith, about twenty men and two women— He performed the usual morning service, according to the forms of the Presbyterian Church, and preached a short Sermon from Hebrews. 6.18. “That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation who have fled, for refuge, to lay hold upon the hope, set before us. 19. Which hope, we have as an anchor of the Soul, both sure and steadfast, and which entereth, into that within the veil”— This Discourse scarcely gave me an opportunity to judge, of the character and power of Mr. Smith as a pulpit orator. What I have seen of him, has given me a very favorable, opinion of him, as a man— He gave notice that owing to the inclemency of the weather, the Church would not be open, for Public Worship, this afternoon— But that there would be a service in it, on Wednesday evening— The Storm continued so severe, that I did not attempt to attend any Church, after dinner;—but employed the time in reading a Poem, on the Immortality of the Soul—Canto first— This work, in manuscript, was sent to me, by its Author, through the hands of Mr. Brinkerhoff—of Ohio—with a request, that I would read, and give my opinion of it— It was said to be written by the Author of a volume, given to me last Spring, by Mr. Knox, on the Philosophy of the plan of Salvation— I have intended, and promised Mr. Knox to read it—but have not yet performed the promise— The Poem is in the form of blank verse—in the construction of which the Author, is very unskilful— It is accompanied with Notes, more voluminous, than the Poem itself, and consists, in the first Canto, of a series of inquires, to ascertain, what is the
Soul— The second Canto, which I had not time this day to read, is intitled, “The work of the Soul”—and the notes, beginning with the doctrine of Plato, dive into all the mysteries, which belong to that, incomprehensible subject— I dread to approach it, and never enter upon it, without remembering, the reprobate spirits in the Paradise lost—“Who find no end, in wandering mazes lost”—

lg.l: Of good and evil who shall draw the line
What matchless hand shall sever right from wrong,
Lord, God Omnipotent, that hand is thine
Strength of the weak, and weakness of the strong—
Right is the purpose of thy whole design
The Laws to thee and Thee alone belong.
Of mortal man beyond the bounded range.
Right, is eternal, and can never change—

div.p:
The above is an effusion, of my nightly waking hours— When without ability to sleep, or energy to rise, time hangs heavy on me, and I seek consolation, in the jingling of rhyme— This happens to me very often, though I have scarcely ever, made any record, of these my thick coming fancies— I propose however to do so, by way of experiment, for a few days, yet left me. This morning we retrieved the arrears, of this Diary—and I then attended at the House— I found them in Session and Felix G. Mc Connell, had made an explanation about his Speech, two or three days since, assailing, the Legislature, of his own State for mis-managment and waste, of the proceeds of the Sale of 400,000. acres of Land, granted by Congress, to aid in the construction, of a Canal, round the Muscle Shoals, of the Tennessee river— The Speaker said this was the day for calling the states and Territories, for resolutions, commencing with the Territory of Iowa, and going upwards to the state of Maine—but James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina called up a Report, of the Committee of Elections, in the contest for the seat of John Runk as a member from New Jersey— John Wentworth of Illinois, urged the call for resolutions, it being the first time, during the present Session, that it was to commence from the west but the House chose to postpone the call for resolutions, and to take up the contested election.— The report of the majority
closed with a resolution, that Isaac. G. Farlee, is not entitled to a Seat, in this House, as a representative from the state of New Jersey— Hannibal Hamlin, from the minority of the Committee of elections, moved to strike out all after the word resolved, and insert that John Runk, is not entitled to a seat upon this floor; that Isaac. G. Farlee, having received a majority, of the legal votes of the legally qualified voters, of the third Congressional District of New Jersey, is entitled to his Seat, upon this floor— Farlee was admitted to a seat on the floor, with the privilege to speak, in support of his claim. The Reports of the majority and minority of the Committee of elections were read— It appeared, that John Runk, was declared to have been elected, by a majority, of 16. votes, but Farlee represented, that this nominal majority was obtained, by the votes of 36. Students, at the Theological Seminary at Princeton, and of 5. Students, at the College, at the same place— The Question then was whether the votes of the students, were by the Laws of New Jersey, legal, and valid the debate was maintained, by Harper and Dobbin, in favor of the students, and resisted by Hamlin and Chipman— All members of the Committee of elections— I found it so dull and tedious, that I left my Seat, and went into the Senate Chamber where I heard a Speech of Sydney Breese, Senator from the State of Illinois upon the Oregon Question, in favor of giving the notice, of termination, to the Convention of 1827. and stubborn, in support of the right to the parallel of Latitude 54–40. The hour rule, of the House, has not been adopted, in the Senate— Soon after three, I returned to the House, where Chipman of Michigan was still speaking, but stopt immediately, for a motion to adjourn, which was carried— I rode to and from the Capitol— The heaviest, of this, and of many winters, subsided, this afternoon, and began to clear off cold—

Mr. Henry Johnson, one of the Senators from the State of Louisiana, with a friend from that state named,This gentleman came, with a request, of my opinion as to the construction, in an article of the Florida Treaty so-called, signed on the 22d. February 1819. and finally ratified
on the 22d. of February 1821. It related to contested Land Titles, in that region of Country claimed by us, as ceded in the Louisiana Treaty of 1803, and by Spain, as not included in that Treaty— That is, west Florida, east of the Mississippi to the Perdido— These Land titles, have been in litigation from the time of the conclusion of the Florida Treaty, and now, a statement of my recollection is requested, as to an understanding, between the negotiaters of the Treaty Don Luis De Onis and myself, at the time. I told this gentleman, that I should very readily, give my recollections upon the subject, but they would have no sort of bearing, for or against any claims to land titles— That the Treaty must of course speak for itself, and at the distance, of 27. years, I could have no confidence, in my own memory, upon points so critical, in the conduct of the negotiation, I could say at once, that Mr. Onis and myself, had commenced the negotiation, by discarding all previous controversy, respecting the right of Jurisdiction, of either party, in the disputed Territory— The King of Spain, had made up his mind, to cede to the United States, all his claims, and rights, to the whole of it, and we considered it altogether useless, to debate any further concerning the previous title, to it— Mr.left for me, a Memorial to the Committee of private Land claims, of the House of Representatives, presented in April 1838. by Richard S. Cox, and Theodore H. McCaleb Council for the Petitioners, with sundry Documents annexed, which I am to examine— I took to the Pension Office for the examination of the Commissioner a Letter from Elijah Clark Esqr. with a return certificate of Pension due to the Heirs of Betty Wheat, and a claim of Jonathan Sargent—and then went to the House, where the Speaker had laid before the House, a report from the Clerk, estimating the cost; of supplying the Reporters with the printed Documents, for the remainder of this Session at about three hundred dollars. The contested election, from New Jersey, between John Runk the sitting member and Isaac. G. Farlee, was resumed. John S. Chipman of Michigan, finished his speech, in favor
of Farlee, and was followed, by Timothy Jenkins, of the 20th. Congressional District of New York, on the same side. They were answered, by E. D. Culver, of New York, Robert Toombs of Georgia, and Robert. C. Schenck, of Ohio—with an overwhelming superiority of talent and of Argument, on the other side— John. W. Tibbatts, of Kentucky moved the Previous Question. and passed four o’clock the House adjourned— Mr. Richard D. Cutts, and his sister Mary, were here this evening— My wife was quite unwell and confined to her bed—
To Mirth— A Sonnet.—

lg.l: Come to my bosom! cheerful smiling Mirth.!
And while the hours of changeful Fortune roll
Come! tune thy timbrel to my weary Soul
And purge my Passions from the dross of Earth.
Thy hand in Eden, at Creations birth
Held to the lip of Man, the flowing bowl
While on his ear the Seraph concert stole
And whisper’d bliss of more than modest worth—
That cup was blameless—and when fallen Man
Expel’d from Eden, by her maker’s ban
Was doom’d to lead a life of woe—and die—
Of all the joys of Paradise bereft
This child with Innocence! Thy voice was left
The pledge of future blessedness on high—

div.p:
Mr. Heman Lincoln called here this morning, and inquired if my Lecture upon Faith, which he had once heard me deliver, had been published— I said it had not— He expressed a desire to read it, and I lent him the fair manuscript copy of it— At the House, the contested election from New Jersey, was the first subject acted upon— After a call of the House, during the course of which I took my seat, and answered at the second call—one hundred and eighty names were returned— The previous Question moved yesterday by Tibbatts was rejected, by Tellers 68 to 75— The resolution reported by the majority of the Committee of Elections was that Isaac G. Farlee is not entitled, to a Seat in this
House, as a representative from the State of New Jersey, but they did not report, that the sitting member, was.— Hannibal Hamlin, from the minority of the Committee, moved to strike out, that Farlee is not entitled to a seat in the House, and to insert, that John Runk is not entitled to a Seat on this floor— That Isaac G. Farlee having received a majority of the legal votes, of the legally qualified voters, of the third Congressional District of New Jersey is entitled to a Seat on this floor— Yancey inquired, if the Question could not be divided, the Speaker answered, that by a positive rule of the House, a motion to strike out and insert, was indivisible— Morse of Louisiana, then asked to be excused from voting in as much as he could vote that Runk was not entitled to the Seat but not that Farlee was— The first Question was upon Hamlin’s amendment, which was rejected by yeas and nays, 76. to 112—then on the Resolution reported by the majority of the Committee, that Farlee is not entitled to the Seat, which was carried 119. to 66— Hamlin then moved that John Runk, is not entitled to a Seat, in this House, and called the previous Question, and yet, attempted to make a Speech— Hopkins of Virginia, moved to lay the whole subject on the Table, which was rejected 93. to 99— The previous Question was then carried, and Hamlin’s motion, that John Runk, is not entitled to his Seat, was lost, 96. to 96—the Speaker deciding the tie, by voting in the negative— Bayly of Virginia then said; that he had agreed with his Colleague Pendleton, called away by urgent business to Baltimore this morning, that if his Bayly’s vote, should turn the scale, he would not give it, Yet he did vote against Runk, and thereby, made the tie— He said he should not have voted if he had known, that the vote would be so close, and this is a sample, of what Mr. Bayly holds to be the obligation of good Faith— But for the decision of the Speaker his vote would have turned the scale, but the promise itself, was unwarrantable— William Sawyer of Ohio complained, of a Letter published in the New
York Tribune, purporting to be, from the Reporter a Letter writer, of that Paper, on the Floor of the House The Clerk read Letter, which was, extremely abusive, and scurrilous, upon Sawyer and one or two other members— Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved, that the Reporters and Letter writers, for the New York Tribune (without naming them) be expelled from this House, and he moved the Previous Question— Washington Hunt of New York moved to lay the resolution on the Table.— Winthrop, raised a question of order, and denied the right of the House, to expel the Reporters— The Speaker overruled the point of order— Garrett Davis, moved to refer the subject to a select Committee— Hilliard moved to adjourn— Hunt withdrew his motion to lay on the Table, and the vote by yeas and nays to expel the Reporters and Letter writers for the New York Tribune, was carried 119. to 48. Robinson, is one of them, and was named as well as the other by Sawyer, but not in the Resolution itself— The House adjourned about four o’clock— Revd. Mr. M. Brown formerly President of the Jefferson College, at Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, was here this evening and left with me, a Letter, soliciting, a contribution, in behalf, of that Institution, which I visited, in November 1843. on my return from Cincinnati— Mr. Brown, has since resigned, the Office of President of that College, and was succeeded, by the Revd. Robertof Baltimore— I do not feel a call, to comply, with a request for a contribution, believing, that the College, ought to support itself, or be supported, by the people of Pennsylvania— My wife was ill, and confined all this day to her bed—

div.p:
I received this morning, a very mysterious confidential Letter, dated New York March the 3d. from William Rysom a total stranger to me, together with two duodecimo volumes published in London 1840. and entitled The Book of Family Crests—a work upon Heraldry—of which I know scarcely anything, and concerning which, I am unable to answer the questions of the writer.
He seems to think that there is a deep plot involved in this publication, but knows as little as I do, what it is. He insinuates that it concerns, a legitimate descendant from Charles Edward once the Jacobite pretender— at the House, when I took my seat, the House was proceeding, in a call, occasioned by a motion, of David. S. Reid, to reconsider, the vote of yesterday deciding the contested election from New Jersey in favour of John Runk, the sitting member, by the casting vote, of the Speaker— Immediately after I took my seat a motion was made to suspend further proceedings on the Call for which I voted— Winthrop came to my seat and told me, that the motion to reconsider was a concerted measure, to reverse the decision, under the voluntary absence, of some Democratic members to secure, a reversal of the decision, without changing their votes—and thus turning Runk out of his seat. The majority of the House refused to suspend the call till a number equal to that, of the yesterday vote, was returned, whereupon Mr. Reid, withdrew his motion to reconsider, and Runk holds his Seat— Dromgole from the Committee Ways and Means, reported sundry articles of Amendment to the proposed sub-Treasury Bill—referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— McKay, Chairman of the same Committee reported the Annual Post Office appropriation Bill— Sundry Reports, on Private Claims, were received and Armistead Burt, of South Carolina reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, a Bill to found a Military Asylum, for the relief and support of Invalid Soldiers of the Army— Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina, reported from the Committee on Naval Affairs a call on the Secretary of the Navy, for retrenchments in that Department; which was adopted— The River and Harbor Bill, was resumed, and Tibbatts moved a resolution, for closing the Debate on that subject, which resolution was laid on the Table, by yeas and nays 88. to 33. Afterwards, the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on this Bill Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair. McKay, moved to postpone it and take up an Appropriation Bill but the Chairman stated that Hudson was entitled to the floor, and McKay’s
motion was not considered— Hudson had been called to Order for discussing the Tariff, in the last Debate on this Bill— The Chairman had pronounced him, in order, and an Appeal had been taken from that decision— It was now confirmed by the Committee and Hudson finished his hour speech— John Pettit of Indiana, followed, in his speech of an hour, abusive enough, upon Hudson, but in support of the Bill. Frederick P. Stanton of Memphis, Tennessee, then took the floor, the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— We had evening visits from the Revd. Dr. John Codman of Dorchester, and from Mr. George Sykes, a member of the House from New Jersey, with three of his friends from that State— My wife continues ill, and unable to leave her bed—
To Miss.

lg.l: Our lots fair Maiden! have been cast
Far distant from each other.
And my career is well nigh past
Yet hoping for another—
There shall we be, while life shall last
As sister and as brother?
Or glowing with intenser flame
Of Lover bear the common name—
But— Time, between us, too has trac’d
A longer broader line
Thy lot is at the threshold plac’d
And at the Postern mine
Then while we travel o’er the waste
In youth—or life’s decline
Still let us bear on land or water
The names of farther and of daughter—
And though on earth, we neer may meet
But distant still remain
And never more each other greet
In pleasure or in pain—
Yet let us in communion sweet
The golden chains retain
Till joining in the world above
They melt in universal Love—

div.p:
At the House, the reading of the Journal of yesterday was dispensed with— James McDowell late Governor of Virginia, appeared and took his seat, as a Member of the House—from the eleventh Congressional district, of Virginia, elected, in the place of William Taylor, deceased.— James. C. Dobbin, of North Carolina, moved a resolution, to pay, out of the fund for pay and mileage for members, milage and pay, to Isaac. G. Farlee from the commencement of the Session, to the 4th. inst while he was contesting the Seat of John Runk— This motion, gave rise, to several rather whimsical incidents— It has been usual, in cases of contested elections by vote of the House, to allow pay and mileage, to the persons contesting, who fail, in establishing their right to the Seat—but these decisions, have often been influenced by Party feelings, as was the case now— Farlee, in the last Congress, had voted against making the allowance, to John. M. Botts, in his contest with John. W. Jones—and now, Robert Schenck, moved to amend the Resolution offered by Dobbin, so as to grant the same allowance, to Botts, for the contest in the last Congress— The Speaker, got rid of this amendment, by deciding, that it was out of order.— John. H. Ewing of Pennsylvania, then moved to amend the resolution, by making the money payable out of the Treasury, but this two was evaded by the Speaker— The Previous Question was moved and carried by yeas and nays, 105. to 46. to pay Farlee— But no allowance was made for Botts—although Schenck, moved to suspend the rules, to offer a resolution, in his favor; but this was refused by yeas and nays, 62. to 110. Tibbatts of Kentucky moved to suspend the rules, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the River and Harbour appropriation Bill, but the House refused— Isaac. E. Holmes, moved as a privilege question, that when the House adjourn it should be over to Monday— The yeas and nays and Tellers, were successively called for, and refused—and Holmes motion was carried by a large majority— The House then went into consideration of Private Bills not objected to— The Bill for the
relief of Col. William Grayson. Henry. S. Clark, of North Carolina, withdrew, his objection against the passage of the Bill, but another member, objected, and it went over The House went into Committee of the whole—Julius— Rockwell—in the Chair, on Private Bills, four of which, were laid aside to be reported, without objection, and forty three, were called and objected to— Samuel Gordon moved that the Committee should rise, in which no quorum voted, the Committee rose, and reported that fact, to the House— Preston King moved to adjourn, which was carried— No visitors this evening—

I received this morning a letter from my Son, enclosing his account for the quarter to the end of the last year. and also a Letter from William S. Russell, dated at Plymouth, the 4th. instt., with a copy of my Hymn, for the 22nd. of December— This copy, gives the date of 1806. but Mr. Russell, supposed, it to have been composed, in 1802. the year, in which I delivered the Anniversary Discourse, in commemoration of the landing of the Pilgrims— Mr. Russell says, he has a work in preparation to be called “Recollections of the Pilgrims, and sketches of Plymouth”—in which he wishes to insert this Hymn,—concerning which he makes some inquiries— He seems not to be aware, that it is published in Mr. Lunts Christian Psalter, which has been adopted, by the first Congregational Church and Society in Plymouth, no. 640— Mr. Kavasales was here, still under the frown of the Secretary of the Navy, with little prospect, of redress— Mr. James P. Espy, was also here, with a small model, of his ventilating instrument, and with, one of his publications, upon his theory of storms— He proposes, to claim some public compensation, from Congress, for his inventions and discoveries in meteoroligy and expects a report from the Committee on Naval Affairs for which he is desirous of engaging my support— He promised to call again, next Monday— Mr. George Sykes
a Member of the House from New Jersey, called here with three other citizens of that state— I had a visit from my Colleague, Mr. Charles Hudson— I had received from Col. Joseph G. Totten Chief Engineer, a Letter enclosing one, to Thomas. C. Amory, of Roxbury, notifying him, of his conditional appointment, as a Cadet, at the Military Academy at West Point— I had also received, a Letter, from the Commissioner of Pensions, with a Pension Certificate, in favor of Susanna Lancy, for arrears, due to Betty Wheat, at the time of her decease, This certificate had already been sent, by me, to Elijah Clark, who had sent it back, with some inquiry whether the Pension, was not payable, to other persons, children of Betty Wheat, I referred it to the Commissioner who returned it to me again, with assurance, that it could be paid, only to Susanna Lancy.— I enclosed it again to Mr. Clark, and rode to the Capitol, where I deposited in the Post Office, my Letters to Mr. Amory and to Mr. Clark, and one to Mr. Clark, enclosing the certificate, and also one to Mr. Totten, acknowledging, the receipt, of his Letter to Mr. Amory— I walked home from the Capitol— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and we had short evening visits, from Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal—

lg.l: Father of Mercies when my Soul
Ascends in humble prayer to thee
The purpose of my will controul
And bid my selfish Passions flee—
When thy forgiveness I implore
For all the wrongs myself have done
Peace to my troubled heart restore
And teach me foul revenge to shun.
Let not my lip with fraudful guile
Forgiveness promise to my foes
Nor let my face assume a smile
While rancour in my bosom glows—
From the recesses of my heart
Resentments bitter stings expel,
Bid all the fiends of hate depart,
And Love alone, my bosom swell—

div.p: I attended Public Worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where the Revd. Dr. John Codman, of Dorchester, performed the service, gave out the 100. Psalm— Before Jehovah’s awful Throne and preached from Isaiah 26.3. “Thou wilt keep him, in perfect peace whose mind is staid on thee, because he trusteth in Thee”— The Discourse was upon peace— When I heard him name his text, I had some suspicion, that it would bear a Political complexion— There are rumors of War prevailing about the Country, fomented, for political purposes, and in some parts of the Country, they have produced, a pious combination, of Ministers of the Gospel, to preach for peace, not in the spirit of the Gospel, but for purposes, altogether worldly— But Dr. Codman, had no such intention. his exhortations were to peace with God—peace of mind— He is Minister of a congregational Church at Dorchester, adjoining the Town of Quincy. Of the Calvanistic creed, and partly educated at Edinburgh in Scotland— He is a man of most estimable private character, and of good understanding not however remarkably eloquent, or eminent as a Preacher— I heard him again in the afternoon at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, where the Rev. Matthew. Hale. Smith, is now the Pastor, and was with him in the Pulpit, performing the services jointly with him— His text was, Romans 15.4—“For whatsoever things were written aforetime, were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope”— The emphatic word of this text was hope, derived from the Scriptures—the exposition of which formed the subject of the Discourse. Miss Cutts was here this evening.— The snow has nearly disappeared, and the Spring is setting in— I have read the Poem in blank verse, upon the Immortality of the Soul, and upon the worth of the Soul— It is accompanied with notes, more voluminous than the verse— Part of which I have read.
To Conscience— A Sonnet—

lg.l: Thou faithful Monitor within my breast!
Plac’d as a Sentinel upon my Soul,
With keen rebuke my Passions to controul
And bend my purpose to Heavens high bequest.
Deep in my bosom be my Laws impress’d
And while the years allotted me shall roll
Guide thou my footsteps to the final goal
In the safe harbour of eternal rest—
And if, by human frailty led astray
My feet shall wander in the darksome day
And do my neighbors wrong in word or deed.
Oh! let Repentance on her swiftest wing
Spur’d by the anguish of thy hallow’d sting
Repair the wrong, and for God’s mercy plead—

div.p:
Mr. Cooley, and Mr. Shepherd from Baltimore, came to invite me to deliver a Lecture before a Military Company of Volunteers in that City, called the Baltimore Blues— Mr. Cooley said of fifty years standing, the most ancient Military Company there— I declined upon the ground of inability, to perform the service— Professor James. P. Espy, called on me again, and presented to me a copy, of his Book on the Philosophy of Storms, a large Octavo volume with a separate Pamphlet in folio being a first report on meteoroligy, adressed to the Surgeon General of the United States Army with numerous Charts, exhibiting the direction of the winds, in the Sorms of the year 1843— Mr. Espy left with me also a Letter soliciting my aid, in support of an application which he has before Congress, for compensation, to him, for his invention of conical ventilators made for Ships, of one of which, he brought with him, a small tin model, and explained to me, its operation. He claims, a sum of $50000. for this invention—and has a Letter, of 9. January 1844 from A. P. Upshur shortly before that time Secretary of the Navy and at that time Secretary of State, expressing the opinion, in unison with that of Capt
Beverly Kennon, that the right to use it, in our Navy, would be cheaply purchased at that price. He has also similar certificates, from Mr. John. Y. Mason, some time Secretary of the Navy, and from Captains William Ramsay, and Charles Wilkes, Lieut Henry Eld, and Dr. Thomas Harris, of the Navy. At the House, this was one of the days for the reception of Petitions, but none were presented—and since the rule, for receiving petitions, at the Clerks table, and having them committed to appropriate Committees, the practise of presenting them publicly, is going into disuse— Several resolutions, from the Legislatures of the States, relating entirely to local concerns, were however, presented and refered George C. Dromgoole from a Select Committee, reported a Bill, to purchase, from Mrs. Madison for $25.000—the unpublished manuscript papers, of her deceased Husband, in her possession— R. P. Herrick of New-York, presented a Memorial from the national reform association, of the United States relating to the Sales of public Land— It was refered to the Committee on public Lands, but the House refused, to order it to be printed— James. I. McKay, of North Carolina, moved a resolution, to close the debate, in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, on the River and Harbour Appropriation Bill, at 1/2 past two, next Wednesday, but the resolution, was laid on the table, by yeas and nays 96. to 77— The House then went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Thomas Smith of Indiana, in the Chair— And took up that Bill Andrew Johnson of Tenn moved an Amendment, and Thomasson of Kentucky made a speech— Felix. G. McConnell upon pretence of a privilege question, introduced a Bill, of which he had given notice, to grant to the head of a family, man, maid or widow, a homestead, not exceeding 160. Acres of public Land— Samuel Gordon of New York State, moved to lay it on the table, but McConell obtained its reference to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Charles J. Ingersoll moved a resolution, that the House would adjourn tomorrow at three oclock, to attend the funeral of Gen John. P. Van-Ness, who died last Saturday evening, having been formerly a Member of this House, from the State
of New-York and recently, Mayor of the City of Washington— The House adjourned without taking the question in this motion— We had an evening visit from Mr. George Sykes, a member of the House of Representatives from New Jersey with two of his friends, from that State—

To. Lieutenant George Thom.
Corps. of Topographical Engineers of the United States—

lg.l: Couldst thou my friend! thy destiny controul.
And with a wish accomplish thy desire
Say! of thy Maker what wouldst thou require?
Come tell me all the secrets of thy Soul—
Before thy Fancy dreams of rapture roll
To perfect happiness thou wouldst aspire—
Wit—wisdom— Fortune bright ambitions fire
Fame— Honor— Glory—the historic scroll—
Or wouldst thou crave exhaustless mines of wealth,
Protracted youth, uninterrupted health,
The transient pleasure of this earthly hall?
Oh! mould thy purpose to thy Maker’s will;
And he thy cup of blessedness shall fill
With peace of mind that shall surpass them all—

div.p:
In the House, a motion made yesterday, that the House should adjourn this day at three o’clock, to attend the funeral of Gen John P. Van Ness, was after a call for the yeas and nays laid on table, without taking them— John Wentworth of Illinois, moved to close the debate in Committee of the whole, on the River and Harbour Bill, at two o’clock P.M. next Tuesday, which after sundry motions to substitute next Friday, and to lay the resolution on the Table, was finally carried, by yeas and nays 106. to 66— Thomas. J. Henley of Indiana, moved that 35000. copies extra, of the report of the Commissioner of Patents, without the list of Patents, and 7,000. copies of the whole Report, be printed, 2000 copies of which, to
be at the disposal, of the Commissioner— Objection being made to this resolution, Henley moved, and carried a suspension of the Rules, and it was received.— John Wentworth, moved to strike out 35000, and insert 100.000, but afterwards substituted 50.000. Andrew Stewart moved to lay the Resolution on the Table; which was lost— Henley said he was apprehensive that some gentlemen, were under the impression, that the Report contained matter relating to the Tariff, which, he was assured it did not, and he sent to the Clerk, a Letter from Edmund Burke the Commissioner, disclaiming all reference to Party politics— The previous Question was moved— Garrett Davis, moved a proviso to limit to three thousand dollars, the profit to the printer, and stated that, the profit on the printing, would be about $20.000. Wentworth’s motion, was rejected by yeas and nays— Garrett Davis, moved again to lay the resolution on the Table, which was again rejected, and it was carried by yeas and nays 127. to 55. The river and Harbour Bill was resumed, in Committee of the Whole, on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair.— James. J. Faran of Ohio, and Samuel Gordon of New York, made speeches in favor of the Bill— Meredith. P. Gentry, took the floor, but the Committee rose.— The Speaker presented several communications, from the executive Departments— William. L. Yancey of Alabama, moved to go into Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, again, to take up the River and Harbour Bill, but there was no quorum on the vote— Henley moved that when the House should adjourn to meet tomorrow at eleven o’clock which was carried— Three successive motions were then made to adjourn— All rejected by yeas and nays, without a quorum, but the fourth trial succeeded 58. to 54. and the House adjourned till 11. o’clock tomorrow— I went into the Senate Chamber, while the dull debate on the Harbour Bill was sleeping in the House, and heard the close of a Speech, by George Evans of Maine, against our title to Oregon, beyond Latitude 49. North, faintly asserting it South of that Line—ardent in its efforts, to refute the arguments, of the New York Senators, in favor of the title, to 54.40. and closing by saying that he did not know whether to vote for giving the notice to terminate the Convention of 1827. or against it— No visitors this evening—
I was awaked, just after three o’clock this morning, by a delightful serenade, under our windows, and rose, but returned to bed, and whiled away two hours, but the composition of the following Sonnet
To the Magnet—

lg.l: Astounding element of hidden power!
Where in the Universe is thy abode?
Where the first mover of thy mystic load?
Where of thy torrent the resistless shower?
Wert thou not fashion’d at creations birth?
When on their wings of fire, the Seraphs rode
And God on Man angelic speech bestow’d
Lost in confusion upon Babel’s tower.
Throughout unbounded space is thy domain—
Millions of worlds adhesive to thy chain,
Are held together by thy wondrous wand,
The throne of God, omnipotent and wise
Bright with eternal splendor in the skies
By thee supported shall forever stand—

div.p:
The House met this morning, at eleven o’clock— I found them in Session— W. W. Campbell of New York, asked leave to offer a Resolution, which was not granted. R. W. Roberts of Mississippi presented a Memorial and Resolutions, of the Legislature of that State, asking grant of lands— Refferred to the Committee on Public Lands. Preston King, of New York, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— No quorum voting— Thomas. B. King, moved a Call of the House— Rejected. A quorum appeared; and the House went into Committee Thomas. Smith of Indiana, in the Chair, and took up the River and Harbour Bill— John Strohm, of Pennsylvania, moved a proviso that no part of the Appropriations of this Bill, should be paid in the ensuing year, if the Tariff of 1842, should be modified, altered or repealed, during the present session of Congress— No question was taken on this motion but Meredith. P. Gentry of
Tennessee, one of the most eloquent Members of the House of the Whig Party, made a powerful hour Speech, in favor of an Appropriation, moved by his Colleague, John. H. Crozier as an Amendment to the Bill, for the completion of the Canal round the Muscle Shoals, of the Tennessee River and against an other Amendment offered by his other Colleague Andrew Johnson, for the purpose of defeating the Bill— Gentry’s speech, was cut off in the midst, by the expiration of the hour, and was followed, by G. W. Jones of Tennessee, and Howell Cobb of Georgia, against internal improvements— Joseph M. Root of Ohio, moved two additional improvements to appropriations to the Harbour of Lake Erie, and William. L Yancey of Alabama vapoured away an hour, against the power of Congress to make internal improvements— Albert Constable of Maryland took the floor, the Committee rose and the House adjourned, to 11. o’clock tomorrow— The debate on the River and Harbour Bill, is so insufferably tedious, that I slipt away from the House to day into the Senate Chamber, and heard Mr. Reverdy Johnson, one of the Senators from Maryland deliver a splendid speech, on the Oregon Notice Question— He handled with great severity, though in courteous language, the Senators, Allen of Ohio, Hannegan of Indiana, Breeze of Illinois and Lewis Cass, of Michigan—who go by the name of the War Party— He was eloquent in declamation against war, yet in favor, of giving the notice to Great Britain of the termination of the non occupation Convention of 1827— In the evening I had a visit from Mr. John. A Dix, one of the Senators, from the State of New York, and returned to him the Courrier des Etats Unis—which he had lent me, containing the French Ministers Guizot’s Speech, made in the House of Peers last June, developing his system, for maintaining a balance of power, on the American Continents to be held by France. A system, which Mr Dix concurs with me in thinking, not to be tolerated by these United States— It is this system, so severely censured by M. Thiers in the House of Deputies, a pamphlet copy of which I have received from Mr. William. R. King, our present Minister in France—

Much of my time is consumed, in preparations for distributing, the Congressional Documents, of which an extra number are printed for distribution among the people— I have heretofore always, made out, at the commencement of every Session, a list of the names of the persons to whom I send them consisting, of my Son, of the Editors of the Newspapers printed in my Congressional District, with one or two at Boston the Councillors, and Members of the Legislature of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, from the Counties, and Towns, composing the District, being twenty two Towns, the whole County of Norfolk, four Towns in Plymouth County, and five in Middlesex— At this Session however, I have long delayed to make out this list— This I have however, now completed, but have an accumulation of Documents, to transmit. I have added to my list, a number of names— The usual number of Documents, furnished to each Member of the House is from twenty five to forty, but at this, and one or two preceding Sessions the number ordered to be printed of certain favorite Documents allow to each Member upwards of 100. I have therefore been obliged to make a double list for the small and the greater number— At the House, W. W. Campbell of New York, one of the four from the City, moved the appointment of a Select Committee, to report if any alterations should be made in the Consular system of the United States, with leave to report by Bill—otherwise— A Committee of five was appointed, consisting of W. W. Campbell, R. F. Simpson of South Carolina, Charles. J. Ingersoll, James. McDowell, the new Member from Virginia, and Robert. C. Winthrop— Mr. McDowell, who was the late Governor of Virginia, came and renewed acquaintance with me at my seat, he having heretofore visited me, about ten years ago. He is from Western Virginia, and a man of splendid talents. William. G. Brown, of Virginia, moved an instruction to the Committee on Pensions, to inquire into the expediency of making more ample provision, for the indigent soldiers, and Pensioners of the Revolution— George Ashman, of Massachusetts, moved an instruction to the Committee on the Judiciary to consider of measures, to enable claimants against the United States, to obtain justice, now denied them— The
object is, to institute a Judicial Tribunal corresponding with the Court of Exchequer in England— A measure often attempted, and not likely to succeed— Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, asked leave to introduce a Bill, to authorize every poor man, in the U.S. who is the head of a family to enter one-hundred and sixty Acres, of the Public domain, without money and without price— A race for popularity, to outrun McConnell; but the leave, was not yet granted— Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, reported for the Committee of Foreign Affairs, a Bill, making Appropriations, for the payment, of two instalments, of the Mexican Indemnities, provided for by the Convention of January 30th. 1843. between Mexico and the United States— These are the instalments paid from the Mexican Treasury, to the Agent of the United States Voss, and for which, according to Mr. John Baldwins statement to me, the Agent Voss, and Waddy Thompson are jointly or se. . .ly yet to account to the Treasury of the United States— After sundry other affairs, of minor interest, the River and Harbour Bill, was again taken up, in Committee, of the whole on the state of the Union— Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair— Albert Constable of Maryland, made an hour speech, in favor of the Bill generally, under an Appropriation for Havre De Grace, in particular— John. F. Collin of the 11th. Congressional District of New York, John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut, Washington Hunt, of New York, Robert. C. Winthrop, made speeches, all in favor of the Bill— Winthrop’s speech, was in his highest style of eloquence. The Committee rose, Jacob Thompson of Mississippi presented a Memorial, from the Legislature of that State, asking a grant of Land for the use of schools.— Refered to the Committee on Public Lands— The House adjourned, till 11. o’clock to-morrow morning— Evening visit from Lieut. George Thom, to whom, Mary Louisa gave the lines I had written for him—

I received some days ago, a pacquet of Newspapers, called the Polynesian, published weekly, at Hono Looloo. Chn? Hawayian Islands, heretofore called Sandwich Islands— Of which paper J. J. Jarves, is the Editor and this morning a second parcel, the two containing a file of the paper, from the commencement
of the year 1845. to the 7. June, of the same year— This is the Island upon which Cook, lost his life, by the hand of a Savage Cannibal— Its present civilization, is one of the wonders, of the age.— A man by the name of Noah Wilson, came this morning, with a proposal, to take a Lease of the vacant Lot in the rear of my house fronting upon G. Street— I am to have it measured, and give him an answer hereafter— At the House, I found Samuel Gordon, of New York complaining, in a personal explanation of having been misrepresented in the New York Herald, but I did not ascertain upon what R. W. Roberts and Jefferson Davis, both of Mississippi, presented Memorials, from the Legislature of that state, craving grants of Public Lands for one purpose, and another.— Robert C. Schenck, of Ohio presented a Petition fromCounty Indiana, for an appropriation, for the improvement of the Maumee river— Hugh. A. Haralson, of Georgia, Chairman of the Military Committee gave notice, that he would move next Wednesday to go into Committee of the whole on the Bill reported by that Committee for the public defenses, and that he would call the yeas and nays, on that motion, until the Bill should be taken up, and acted upon— John. R. J. Daniel moved to go into Committee of the whole, on private Bills, which the House refused, but went into Committee on the state of the Union, on the River and Harbour Bill— Archibald Yell of Arkansas, gave notice of his intention to move, a proviso, to be added, to the item for removing the raft in the Red river— James. Thompson of Pennsylvania, Bradford R. Wood of New-York, and Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio, made Speeches in support of the Bill— That of Vinton embracing an Argument for the constitutionality of internal improvement appropriations— Stephen Adams of Mississippi opposed the Bill, and Luther Severance, of Maine supported it— Stephen Douglass of Illinois ostensibly did the same, but his Speech was a firely hot blast for Oregon and 54.40. Howell Cobb of Georgia, E. H. Ewing of Tennessee, and Seaborn Jones of Georgia offered amendments, to Bill the Bill— Joseph R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of $3000 for a Survey and investigation of the river Delaware, to construct See Harbours. It was five o’clock when the House adjourned to 11. o’clock tomorrow morning— Evening visit from Capt. John. C. Casey of the Office of the
14. VI Commissary General of subsistance—

I received this morning two Letters, one, from Jonathan Amory, of Roxbury and one from Thomas Isaac Coffin his Son, acknowledging, the receipt of his conditional warrant of admission to the Military Academy at West point— In the first entry of his name at the Department of War, there had been an error— It was entered. Thomas C. Amory his real name is Thomas. Isaac Coffin Amory This error is to be rectified at the Office of the Chief Engineer At the House, a Bill was passed, regulating the value, of certain European coins. Charles. J. Ingersoll, from the Committee of Foreign Affairs, reported a Bill, to provide for the enforcement of certain provisions, in the Treaty with Prussia and some others. He reported also, the correspondence with the Spanish Minister, concerning discriminatory tonnage duties, referring to a Bill, reported on the 16th. last January and made the special order, for the 21st. of next April— A preemption Bill reported by Thomas Smith of Indiana, from the Committee on the Public Lands, was referred to the Committee of the whole, after some struggle by Smith—and Charles W. Cathgart from the same state to drive it through, without examination— Sundry private Bills were reported, and Robert Smith of Illinois, from the Committee on Roads and Canals reported a resolution, to make, the Bill appropriating $400.000 for the continuation of the Cumberland road, in the states of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois the special order for the 23. instt. but failed to carry the resolution, by a vote of 69 to 52. not two thirds. The river and Harbour Bill, was resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith in the Chair, and was debated by John. W. Houston the member from Delaware, Edward. D. Baker, of Illinois, James. A. Seddon of Virginia, each of whom offered an Amendment for additional appropriations, and by Thomas. H. Bayly of Virginia, and Andrew Stewart of Pennsylvania upon the Constitutionality of internal improvements after which the Committee rose, and the House, adjourned to Monday next at twelve o’clock— We read this evening in Littells Living Age, the lamentable tale of the Life of Laman Blanchard—by Sir Edward Bulwer Lytton—

This morning I finished reading the Book of Joshua; having read two Chapters a day from the first of December last— I attempted the composition of some lines, suited to the day, but without success— It is impossible to foresee at any time the hours of poetic inspiration— I attended at 11. o’clock the service of Public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where Mr. Milburn, the Chaplain of the House of Representatives, preached from Genesis, 49.10—“The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a law giver from between his feet, until Shiloah come, and unto him shall the gathering of the people be”— This text requires an exposition more comprensive than is embraced, by the learning or the capacity of Mr. Milburn— Very few preachers of the Gospel, are competent to it, though it appears to be a favourite topic, with many of them.— Historically speaking it requires much explanation; it is usually understood as refering to the advent of Jesus Christ— And why is he called Shiloah? And why is it said, that the Sceptre shall not depart from Judah, until he come? I walked to, and from the Capitol, and after dinner at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, heard Mr. Matthew Hale-Smith preach from Romans. 9.16. “So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God, that sheweth mercy.” This Chapter contains the principal argument of Saint Paul to establish the doctrines of election and pre-destination— Mr. Smith observed, that in the Epistle of Peter, it is said “That there are in the writings of the Apostle Paul, some things hard to be understood”—and that this remark is especially applicable to this passage, of the Epistle to the Romans.— It seems to import, that the mercy of God, is not obtainable by the will or the exertions of man, but that it is merely the result, of the arbitrary will of the Creator— The Apostle appears aware, that the doctrine is susceptible of great objection. In the preceding context, he says [“]It is written Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated,[”] and then he enquires [“]what shall we say then is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid, for he saith to Moses I will have mercy, on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion, on whom I will
have compassion,” and in the subsequent context—he adds “thou wilt say then unto me, why doth he yet find fault, for who hath resisted his will[”] and to this he replies, Nay, but O man who art thou, that repliest against God, shall the thing formed, say to him that formed it, why hast thou made me thus? This may be called cutting the gordion Knot, but is no answer to the objection— The whole Chapter deserves deep meditation—

I went this morning, to the Office of Col Totten the Chief Engineer, to have rectified, the name, of Thomas Isaac Coffin Amory, to whom, a warrant of Cadet, at the Military Academy at Westpoint, had been sent— I found it already done, and answered the Letters, of this young gentleman and of his Father— From the Engineer Office I proceeded to the Capitol, and found, the House of Representatives in Session.— The reading of the Journal of Saturday, had been dispensed with, and they were in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith in the Chair upon the river and Harbour appropriation Bill. Edward. H. Ewing of Nashville Tennessee, was arguing the Constitutional power, of Congress to establish and maintain a general system of internal improvement— He quoted from the Federalist, and pronounced a magnificent panegyric, upon the purity of character, of Alexander Hamilton, His hour closed, while he was discoursing, upon the necessity of Appropriations for the improvement of the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers— He was followed by Asa Biggs, with an argument against the Constitutionality of appropriations for internal improvement, and gave notice, that he should move an appropriation for re-opening Roanoke inlet, at or nearhead in North Carolina one hundred thousand dollars.— Thomas Perry of Maryland, moved an additional section to the Bill, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to transfer, to the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company all the stock of the United States in that Company, upon suitable conditions— Mr. Perry too has Constitutional scruples, about the power of
Congress, to make internal improvements, and said he should discriminate in his votes, between the items, which in his opinion were, and those which were not within the pale of the Constitution. Richard. P. Herrick of New York, moved an appropriation $5000— for the improvement of the Navigation of the Hudson River, at what is called the over— John H. Ewing of Pennsylvania, made an hour speech, in favour of internal improvement, and in reprobation, of the annexation of Texas.— George Rathbun, of New York, spoke in favor of appropriation on the Harbours of the Lakes, and against the purchase of the Louisville and Portland Canal. John A. McClernand of Illinois, defended, the Democratic Party, against the charges of inconsistency and discordance, made by Ewing of Pennsylvania, and then referring to the Oregon Question noticed the coincidence between the Resolution offered by Robert C. Winthrop to refer the subject to Arbitration and the subsequent proposal from the British minister to the same effect— Mr. Winthrop very solemnly disclaimed any knowledge, of the intention of the British Government to make this proposal, when he offered his resolution Mr. McClernand, was strongly opposed to the appropriation proposed in the Bill of $75.000. for the Harbour of Saint Louis— The substituted member from Florida, Brockenbrough, made an hour speech against the Constitutionality of appropriations for internal improvements, and bitterly complained, that Florida, which has cost the Union more than fifty millions of dollars, had not had her share, of the Public monies— Jefferson Davis, of Mississippi piped out his hour, to the same tune, complaining that all the money of the people, was raised at the South, and expended at the East, the direct reverse of which, is much nearer the truth— It was now past five o’clock— Joseph A. Woodward of South Carolina, took the floor, motion was made for the Committee to rise; no Quorum The Committee rose and reported the fact, motions to adjourn and for a call of the House, were alternately made, and rejected, till past seven o’clock, when a motion for a call was carried— I saw there were hours of idleness, and no business for the night, in prospect, answered at the call of my name, and immediately left the House and came home— The call
was continued, till half past nine o’clock, when a number of members, were brought to make their excuses in the House, which then adjourned, to ten oclock tomorrow morning— When I got home, I found my dear wife very ill, in bed— Dr. Thomas was sent for, came, and prescribed, with a promise that she would be better to-morrow— We had evening visits from Mr. Healey, Mr. Doubourjal and Mr. Carter Lee—

Saint Patricks day— I had received from W. E. Robinson, for himself, and Peter Brady, G. D. Dowlin, Edmund Stubbs, John Boyd and Thomas Donahue, an invitation to attend as a guest, at a public dinner this day, at Carusi’s Salon, in honor, of Ireland’s patron saint, which I declined in consideration, of my infirm health and recent domestic affliction— At the House, which met at 10. o’clock Tibbatts moved to dispense with the reading of the Journal, but Dromgoole objected, and it was read.— He then said, that there was a statement in the Journal: that all the Members who came into the Hall last evening, ending the call, were brought in, in custody of the Sergeant at Arms, which he believed was not the fact. The Clerk read the Journal, which stated, that the Sergeant at Arms, came into the Hall, with the following named members, giving their names.—Dromgoole said he wished to separate the names to distinguish those who came in, voluntarily and those, who were really brought in by the Sergeant at Arms—to save the House, from the payment of the fees, whereupon Atkinson, and several others, denied, having been brought in, by the Sergeant at Arms, and the Speaker said, the Journal would be corrected and so the petty-pride, of the delinquents, was spared the mortification of appearing upon the record, as prisoners to the Sergeant at Arms— Houston of Alabama, at the discipline of the call of the House, had not been completely carried through last night, several members, whose names went on the Journals, as absentees, in custody and on trial, had yet to be excused—he was for resuming the process, but the Speaker said that an adjournment put an end, to all unfinished proceedings in a call of the House— The river and Harbour Bill, was then resumed, in Committee of
the whole on the state of the Union. Thomas Smith in the Chair, Joseph. A. Woodward of South Carolina, made an hour speech, against the Constitutional power of Congress—to appropriate money for internal improvements, followed by James. B. Bowlin of Saint Louis Missouri, in a volunteer, and quite unneccessary defence of the West against the charge, of plundering the public Treasury, and retorting the charge, not against South Carolina, whence it came, but upon the East more odious to South Carolina, than the West itself— Tibbatts of Kentucky and McClernand, of Illinois, had some altercation, about appropriations for the benefit of the West— Cocke of Tennessee supported the Amendment moved by his Colleague Crozier, about the Muscle Shoals, and Daniel P. King of Massachusetts, moved three additional appropriations within that state— Joshua. F. Bell. of Kentucky offered an Amendment but had not time to make a speech, the hour of two, having arrived which had been previously fixed, for voting upon the proposed Amendments, and taking the Bill out of Committee from that time till about five o’clock a multitude of Amendments, were proposed and adopted or rejected in Committee, as the humor of the majority directed— When the Committee rose and the House adjourned— We had evening visits from General and Mrs. Jesup, and from an old acquaintance whom I had not for a long time seen Carter Lee—

My wife continued ill, confined to her bed all day yesterday, but is this day convalescent though not yet able to leave her chamber— The Senate, have expelled from their Hall the reporters, of the newspaper published in this City called the daily Times—for certain charges against certain nameless Senators, of having corrupt dealings with the British Minister Pakenham, for a compromise of the Oregon Question— A few days since the House of Representatives, expelled from their reporters seats, the correspondents of the New York newspaper called the Tribune, for exposing to ridicule the manners, and not the character of William Sawyer a Member of the House from Ohio.
This sickly sensibility, to the animadversions of the Press, manifested by arbitrary acts, of power, unchecked by Judicial controul, seems to be common, to all deliberative assemblies; and always terminates, to their disadvantage— This morning Mr. Sawyer, of Ohio made a personal explanation, with reference to a report of his speech yesterday, in the National Intelligencer of this day, and was followed by his Colleague Mr. Delano, also, with a personal explanation— John. P. Martin of Kentucky from the Committee on Mileage, reported a resolution to discharge the Committee of the whole, from the further consideration of the mileage Bill, which was adopted— James. B. Bowlin of Missouri, then moved an Amendment to the Bill, to retrench the pay, of every Member of the House, for every day of his absence from it, and even, for every absence failure to answer upon any call of the House, or of the yeas and nays— Thomas Perry, of Maryland, moved to lay the Amendment on the Table; which the House refused— Archibald Yell of Arkansas, moved to amend Bowlin’s Amendment, by reducing the pay, of members, to six dollars, a day, and for every twenty miles travel— Also an additional section, to remove the seat of Government of the United States, from the year 1850. to a place near Saint Louis, in the State of Missouri— Bowlin accepted this, as a part of his Amendment, and George W. Jones of Tennessee, moved to substitute instead of Saint Louis, Jeffersonville in the State of Indiana, on the avowed ground, that if the seat of Government, was to be removed, it should be into a free State; whereupon George. C. Dromgoole of Virginia, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the river and Harbour Bill—which was done.— The voting upon the amendments was resumed— A multitude of Amendments were proposed. Some of them, in derision, and for very unwarrantable sport Among them, one by George Fries, of Ohio, grossly and personally insulting, to his Colleague Schenck, which occasioned an altercation, and a retort from Schenck, upon which a full hour of the House was wasted, and the time disgracefully lost— The yeas and nays were taken upon numerous Amendments, the first, upon a provision, of five thousand dollars, for removing the obstructions—
from the Harbour, at Providence Rhode Island; upon which Lynn Boyd of Kentucky, called for the yeas and nays, and it was carried, 99. to 96. The appropriation of $15.000, for removing the obstructions of Newark Bay New Jersey, was also carried, by yeas and nays 98. to 89— Crozier of Tennessee, had moved, an item of $100.000., for the Muscle Shoals, which was lost by yeas and nays, 65. to 125. and thereupon, Crozier, who had voted for the appropriation of $5000. for Providence Harbour, moved a reconsideration of that vote, which was lost by yeas and nays 95. 102. This is a specimen, of the slave monger system, of internal improvements— 1/2 past 3. o’clock the House adjourned— Evening visit from Mr. Abel Shawk. who requested me, to call and have my portrait taken by Daguerreotype Machine, at Plumb’s Gallery—in the Pennsylvania Avenue, at 11. o’clock to-morrow morning—to which I assented—

I received this morning a Letter from Mr. Sleeper with two voluminous manuscripts of the correspondence, of George. W. Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio De Janeiro, with the Secretary of State Buchanan, concerning the Slave Trade— On my way to the Capitol this morning I stopped at Plumb Gallery where several Daguerreotype likenesses were taken of me by the improved Machine, of Mr. Abel Shawk, and I promised to call again tomorrow morning for some others to be taken, one of which for myself At the House the voting by yeas and nays upon many items, of the river and Harbour appropriation Bill, was resumed— Under the new rule, of taking a separate vote, on the engrossment of a Bill, for every item of appropriation, if required, by one fifth of the Members present. Lynn Boyd, called for yeas and nays on an item of five thousand dollars, for the improvement of S.Bay on Lake Ontario. Carried 103. to 83— Again on an item of $7000. of the improvement of Oak Orchard Harbour, state of New York. Carried 94. to 87— Again $40000. for the improvement of St Clair flats, on Lake Michigan— Carried, 117. to 70— $40.000, for improving
of Michigan City; carried 99. to 81— For the improvement of Little Fort Harbour, on Lake Michigan $12.000— For improving the Harbour at Saint Louis Missouri, $75.000— For removing obstructions in Newark Bay New-Jersey $15.000. For improving the Harbour at Havre de Grace Maryland, $20000.— All of which were carried. when Seaborn Jones of Georgia, under a surfeit of yeas and nays, and of internal improvements, rose and said, that Mr. Colquit one of the Senators from Georgia had lost a child, the funeral of which to take place, this afternoon, the Delegation from Georgia, wished to attend, and he therefore moved the House to adjourn, which was carried, without opposition— This evening, with Mrs. John Adams, Walter Hellen, and Mary Louisa, I attended a Concert, at Carusi’s Saloon, given by Leopold De Meyer, the performer of wonders, upon the grand Piano—assisted by an indifferent Singer named Wood— The House was crowded, and the performance, said to be, quite extraordinary— De Meyer, has the reputation, of being one of the finest performers, of the age. He was at his own request, introduced to me, after the performance was over, and I thanked him very sincerely, for the entertainment of the evening—

lg.l: Lord! thou hast made me weak and frail
And ever prone to fall.
Presumptuous Sins my Soul assail
And fears my heart appal—
For blessings on my life to thee
My daily prayer ascends.
While yet against the wise decree
My stubborn will contends—
In silent Solitude I feel
The justice of thy laws.
And when in penitence I kneel
To plead my guilty cause
When prostrate at thy feet I bow
Thy mercy to implore,
My lips repeat the solemn vow
To go and Sin no more—
E’en then within me lurks a foe
My purpose to betray
Who still besets me as I go
And meets me on the way
Before me spreads Temptations snare,
And echoes Passions call—
And if one instant unawares,
I stumble, and I fall—
Oh! God of mercy! God of Grace,
Exert thy boundless power
My Soul with Resolution brace
To meet Temptations hour.
From Earth to Thee my spirit raise
Thy statutes to fulfil
And live the remnant of my days
Accordant to thy Will—

div.p:
My morning’s meditation before the dawn of day— On my way to the Capitol, I called again at Plumb’s Gallery, and he took four Daguerreotype Likenesses of me, one of which, he afterwards sent me, as a present— At the House, the River and Harbour Bill, was at last disposed of, before which the Speaker presented to the House, a Letter from the Secretary of War the report of Capt. J. Allen, of the first Regiment of Dragoons of his expedition last Summer to the heads of the Des Moins Blue Earth, and other rivers, in the north west, called for, by a resolution of the House; referred to the Committee on Military Affairs— The first Question taken by yeas and nays, on the River and Harbour Bill, was upon an item of $25.000 for improving Hog Island Channel at Charleston City—South Carolina— The call for the yeas and nays was by W. W. Woodworth, of the 8. Congressional District of New York merely for retaliation upon the members from South Carolina, for voting against, all the other appropriations; The vote was 82 to 86, and the appropriation, was lost by the votes of the South Carolina Members themselves, James. A. Black, Richard. F Simpson, Joseph. A Woodward, Alexander D. Simms, Armistead Burte
and Robert. Barnwell. Rhett, all voting against it Six out of seven— Isaac. E. Holmes, of Charleston, did not vote— If the South Carolina Members had voted for the appropriation, it would have been carried 88. to 80, without Holmes vote— The chalice, was thus effectually returned, to their own lips— The next item $50.000. for the improvement of Savannah Harbour, and the naval anchorage, near Fortwas carried 166. to 77—and then an item of $4.450 for the improvement of Great Wood hole Harbour Massachusetts by a vote of 100. to 89— The purchase, of the stock of the Louisville and Portland Canal, was rejected 56 to 131— The item, for continuing the improvement of the Hudson River, above and below Albany $75.000, was carried, 102. to 79— and for the improvement of the Ohio river, above the Falls at Louisville $80.000. by 112 to 72—and below the Falls of Louisville and of the Mississippi, Missouri, and Arkansas rivers $240.000. by 118. to 67.— Hilliard of Alabama moved to reconsider the vote rejecting the item of $25.000, for the Channel at Charleston, but it was refused, 73. to 100— The Question upon the engrossment of the Bill was then taken, carried and the Bill was passed, after a motion by George. S. Houston of Alabama, to lay it on the Table; rejected; 86. to 109, and the passage of the Bill was carried 110. to 91.— The title of the Bill, was, “An Act making Appropriations for the improvement of certain Harbours and Rivers”— W. W. Paine of Alabama, moved to Amend the title, to read “An Act making appropriations, for works of internal improvement, within the States[”]— Rhett called for the yeas and nays on this notable amendment, which was rejected 81. to 117. The title was then suffered to pass without call for yeas and nays— Tibbatts moved a re-consideration of the vote, by which the Bill was passed, which the House refused, and the House adjourned, over to next Monday. A singular visitor by the name of Reese Price from Cincinnati.— was here this evening— A self constituted Prophet of spurious inspiration, who foretold a general revolution of Governments, throughout the World, Mr. John Connell, Major James. D. Graham, and Isaac Hull Adams, spent also, part of the evening here—

Mr. Kavasales called upon me this morning, and produced a Letter from Com. Reed, to Charles. J. Ingersoll, who had written to Capt Reed, recommending him, to him to take Mr. Kavasales with him as Chaplain, he being about to embark, as Commander of the Squadron, on the coast of Africa, and in the Mediterranean— Capt Reed answers, that he would with pleasure take Mr. Kavasales, as his Chaplain, but that the Commanders are not allowed, to name all the Officers, who go out with them, and he thinks the application to the Secretary of the Navy, in behalf of Mr. Kavasales would be more effective, coming from an other quarter— I took this Letter with me, to the Navy Department, but the Secretary Bancroft, was in Cabinet Council at the Presidents, and I could not see him— I mentioned to the Chief Clerk, the Letter from Commodore Reed, to Charles. J. Ingersoll, and earnestly recommended, that Mr. Kavasales, who is now upon furlow should be ordered to accompany Capt Reed, which the Clerk assured me, he would report to the Secretary. I then took, to the Commissioner of Pensions a Letter from Elijah Clark of Brighton, making inquiries concerning the Pension Claim, of Ann Weston, and one from Wm. K. Hoyt, of New-York concerning the Claims of Ann Pearsee, Elizabeth Lutz, Maria Blouvelt, widow of Lieut. P. Powles and Mary Winship— Mr. Edwards, told me that he had answered, in relation to these cases, several weeks ago— I found that one of them, was an application to Congress— I went out to Mr. Stone’s House, on the College Hill, where I found, that he had not yet commenced, upon the Bust which he proposes to take of me— But I saw that of Miss Maria Bache, and a very fine marble Bust of Stone himself, by Powers, and sent by him from Florence— I walked home, and was joined on my way by a student at the College, by the name of Tilson, from Vermont— The present President of the College, is Mr. Bacon— In the evening, Mr. Hellen, and Mary Louisa, went to Leopold De Meyer’s second Concert— My wife is still confined to her chamber— No visitors—

At the House, on Friday last, my Colleague Mr. George Ashman, whose seat is immediately before mine, told me that this was his daughters birth-day— He had written her a Letter of congratulation, and was very desirous, of enclosing with it, an autograph of mine—whereupon I immediately wrote, and gave him, the lines of which the following are a copy—
To Miss Lucy Hooker Ashman—

daughter of Hon George Ashman, of Springfield
Massachusetts, on her birth day 20. March 1846.
aged 14—

lg.l: Fair Maiden may thy lot on Earth,
True to the Season of thy birth
A blissful Life display.
And Time, with never flagging wing
With joys at each returning spring
Bring round thy natal day

div.p: I wrote also two others, copies of verses, which I will not here repeat, one, for Miss Camp of Owego, and the other for Miss Cornelia B. Joy of Ovid, both in the state of New York, for autographs— Ovid, seems to be a place, well suited for poetic inspiration— This day I attended Public worship, at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where Mr. Tustan, the Chaplain of the Senate, officiated, and the preacher was a stranger and from his accent I infer an Irishman, His text, was from 1. Corinthians, 10.3. “And did all eat, the same spiritual meat. 4. And did all drink, the same spiritual drink, (for they drank, of that spiritual rock, that followed them, and that rock was Christ)”— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us, and Walter Hellen dined out at his mother’s— After dinner, at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, Mr. Matthew. Hale Smith preached, from Ecclesiastes. 7–10. “Say not thou, what is the cause, that the former days, were better than these, for thou dost not enquire, wisely, concerning this”— Mr. Smith said, that this text, was applicable, to the present time, for the best of all reasons, that the former days were not better than these—
Happiness— A Sonnet—

lg.l: What in the source of Happiness below?
Where in Creations compass can be found
The priceless gem within whose veins is bound
Unmingled pleasure in this world of woe?
Is it in Riches? Riches answer—No!
In Power?— In Glory?— In the Trumpets sound!
The The Plaudits of the Universe around?
The throne imperial? or the vanquished foe?
Methinks, descending from the skies, I hear
A voice angelic, whisper to mine ear—
Tis not in Joy that perfect bliss resides
Tis in the realms of Sorrow, and of Pain
The Martyrs crucifix—the Captives chain,
In Virtue’s arms that Happiness abides—

div.p:
I awaked between two and four in the morning, and unable to sleep again, racked my brain for verses, till the dawn of day permits me, to rise— This is one of the physical developements, which returns upon me, frequently, in the Spring of the year; continues some times for weeks together until a close approach to distraction breaks it off— The above search for happiness, is one of its symptoms; which wasted the hours of this morning— At the House, this was the day for the presentment of Petitions, and the Speaker called, on the state of Rhode Island and then on Massachusetts I had a Memorial, from the Massachusetts Historical Society, which I desired to present. And before I could do so, Hugh Haralson of Georgia—Chairman of the Military Committee, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and to take up the Bill to raise two Regiments of Riflemen reported by him, very early in the Session— I stated to the Speaker, my wish to present the Memorial, from the Massachusetts Historical Society, and reminded him that he had called the state of Massachusetts for
petitions, but he would not hear me, and said he had called the State of Massachusetts, by mistake— The House went into Committee, and took up the Bill, to raise two Regiments of Riflemen, and for other purposes John. I. McKay of North Carolina, in the Chair— Thomas Smith of Indiana, moved to Amend the Bill, from reducing it from two Regiments to one. The Bill was debated, by William Sawyer of Ohio—Jacob Brinkerhoff of the same State, Felix. G. McConnell of Alabama, Lynn Boyd of Kentucky, Hannibal Hamlin, of Maine, James. A. Black of South Carolina, Haralson of Georgia, Archibald Yell of Arkansas Edward D. Baker of Illinois—John. S. Chipman of Michigan—E. W. McGaughey of Indiana, until Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina, took the floor moved an Amendment, and then, the Committee to rise— A Message was received, from the President, which was received with ears all erect, expecting, some new Oregon Negotiation, and an instant demand that it should be read, terminating in a general laugh, when found only to be a correspondence, concerning the payment of certain Duties Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means— Haralson, offered a resolution to close all debate, on the Bill to raise two Regiments of Riflemen— But a motion was immediately made, amid shouts of no, no, no, from all parts of the House, to adjourn, which was carried without opposition. Evening visit from Mr. Hogan— A young man, the son of an old acquaintance, but whom I had not before known—

I have received from Albert Gallatin, the first volume of the transactions, of the American Ethnological Society—Of which he is President, located at New York, and the objects of which, are declared to comprise inquiries, into the origin, progress, and characteristics, of the various races of Man.— I have also received, from Mr. John Jay, Domestic Corresponding Secretary of the New York Historical Society, a volume, containing, the pro-
ceedings of that Society, for the year 1845—and have only to lament, that I have neither time or capacity, to give a proper attention to their contents. Before repairing to the House, this morning, I went to the Pension Office, with a Letter from Alonzo Taft, which I left with Mr. Edwards, containing inquires concerning certain Papers, which Mr. Taft says, he put into my hands, in September 1842— Mr. Edwards promised to inquire and report to me, whether those papers were at the Pension Office, or not— My own recollection of them, is quite indistinct— I then proceeded to the Capitol, where at the House, the reading of the Journal was dispensed with. The resolution offered by Hugh. A Haralson, last evening, at the adjournment, to close the debate, for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen, and for other purposes, at three o’clock this day; and after an ineffectual motion of R. W. Roberts, to lay it on the table, was adopted without a division— Haralson immediately moved to go into Committee which was carried. Felix. G. McConnell moved to lay the Bill aside, and take up another, but the Chairman McKay, declared this not in order— A debate ensued, and continued, until 3. o’clock, when the voting commenced, upon the Amendments proposed to the Bill; one of which was rejected and another adopted— While the process was going on of taking these votes by Tellers, Robert. C. Winthrop came to my seat, and told me, he should vote for this Bill.— I said I regretted again to part from him, for that I had come to the determination to vote against it— The Senate not having acted upon the Bill for giving Notice to the British Government of the termination of the Convention of 1827, and the balance, of probability now being, that the Senate would not pass it at all. He said that a message had been received in the Senate, from the President in answer to a Resolution of that body, offered some days since, by Mr. Dayton, in which the
President, declares explicitely, that in his judgment the present position of the Country does require, an addition to its armed force— Hereupon I rose and moved that the Committee should rise, to enable me, to move in the House, a reconsideration of the vote, by which it had been determined, to take the Bill out of Committee, at 3. o’clock this day— An immediate, and violent opposition, was made to my motion, with loud calls to order— I asked leave to state my reason, for the motion I had made; but the objections and calls to order, continued and increased, during which, I made out, to give my reason, which was, that a message had been received in the Senate from the President, which in all probability would decide my vote and perhaps that of the House, upon the Bill— The struggle, against granting me the leave, to assign my reasons was so vociferous, and peremptory that the Chairman McKay, without taking the Question upon it, said, that he had been mistaken, in supposing that the Committee had assented to give me the leave, and ordered me to take my seat—which I did— Tellers were then called upon my motion for the Committee to rise, and 82 Members, were reported by the Tellers, in the affirmative— This was a majority of the voters present, and the Committee rose— The Chairman, said, that the Resolution in the House, did not require that the Question upon the Bill should be taken this day, that it might be still debated in the House. I replied, that it came to the same thing that if the Bill should be reported, the previous Question would be called and the Question upon the Bill immediately taken. The Committee having risen, I made my motion for reconsideration of the vote, for taking the Bill out of Committee this day— Thomasson of Kentucky and Albert Smith of New York, immediately moved to adjourn— George W. Jones of Tenn. enquired of the Speaker if I had voted for the Resolution, which I now moved to reconsider? The Speaker said that this Question would be in order,
when the motion to reconsider, should come up I had voted against the Resolution, and according to the Rules of the House, was not competent, to make the motion to reconsider, but my object was attained by the rising of the Committee and the adjournment of the House, which immediately followed— We shall know the purport of the President’s message to the Senate, before taking the final vote on the Bill In the evening a Mr. Leffenwell and another person from New Jersey, made us visits, merely of curiosity
