Morning visit from Mr. Robert Owen, who told me, that he should leave the City to-morrow, about to embark for England, where he proposed, to use his best exertions for procuring the amicable adjustment, of the differences, existing between the Government of that Country, and the United States, and he enquired if I had read an article signed by him, in the National Intelligencer of this morning— I had seen his signature but passed over the article taking it for the repetition of one published some days since— He told me the substance of it, which was, that a final settlement should be made, with the least loss of time, on the base of the 49. degree of Latitude to the Pacific with Van Couver’s Island to the British, and the free navigation of the Columbia River for ten years— He hoped that I would concur with him in this opinion— I told him, that I wished him all possible success in his exertions to preserve the peace between the two Countries, which I believed, to be in no sort of danger, but that as to the terms of settlement, the whole range of my ideas both as to right and expediency, were directly the reverse of his— That I believed our right, to Latitude 54–40 on the South Sea, was perfect, with the single exception of actual possession; that Great Britain had no right there, of permanent possession, at all; that with regard, to War and Peace, considered in the abstract,
I agreed with him, and with all benevolent and humane, throughout the World, I held it in utter abhorence—as much so, as the Roman mother’s in the days of Horace and of Augustus Caesar.— But that there are and always have been, as long as the race of men has existed, times and occasions, of dire necessity for War—and philosophically speaking, I believed that War, was not a corrupter, but rather a purifier, of the moral character of Man.— That peace was the period of corruption to the human race, and I asked him, if he recollected the passage, of the Paradise Lost, in which the Ark Angel Michael, after the fall of Adam, foretells to him, the fortunes of his posterity, in War and Peace, after describing to him all the horrors of War, draws before him a picture of his condition in Peace, and such it is, that Adam in contemplating it says—

lg.l: “I had hope,
When violence was ceased, and war on earth,
All would have then gone well, peace would have crown’d
With length of happy days, the race of Man
But I was far deceived for now I see
Peace to corrupt, no less than War to waste.”

div.p:
Mr. Owen, did not recollect the passage in Milton; probably never having read it. but he expatiated upon his anticipations of the universal revolution, started by him, and now in progress, and which will soon, transform and exalt the nature of Man, to be gouverned, by the laws of God, and not by circumstances, and the Laws of Man— He thought that his purposes and mine were the same, the ultimate improvement, and exaltation of the nature of Man and his condition, upon earth, but the means by which we believe this revolution is to be effected are widely different. Mr. Owens visit, delayed my departure for the Capitol, so that when I reached the House, I found them in session, having laid on the Table, my motion to reconsider, the vote for taking the Bill out of Committee yesterday, no longer necessary and they were already in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, taking the
Questions on the several Amendments to the Bill for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen— A substitute for the Bill itself, had already been adopted, by authorizing the President, at his discretion, to increase the number of Privates in each Company, of the existing Regiments, of Dragoons, Artillery, and Infantry to any number not exceeding 80. The enlistment to be, for three years, unless sooner disbanded, by the President— The Bill was thus reported to the House.— Joseph McDowell of Ohio, moved to lay it on the Table, which was rejected by yeas and nays 32 to 149.—and then the Bill was passed, by yeas and nays 164 to 15. Bowlin of Ohio moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the Bill to raise a Regiment of mounted Riflemen and for establishing Military Posts on the route to Oregon.— The House accordingly went into Committee Preston King in the Chair—but instead of Bowlin’s Bill took up at motion of McKay, the Bill to supply deficiencies, and appropriations, for certain objects made for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30. 1846. Upon which a debate arose, and sharp altercation between W. W. Paine of Alabama, and R. C. Winthrop about the Hartford Convention, blue-lights and the party warfare of 1812. till at 4. o’clock the Committee rose, McKay moved a resolution to close debate on this Bill, at 3. p.m. tomorrow, and the House adjourned— No evening visitors, but we read, Benetts New-York Herald, and Shakespeare at Paris from Littells Living Age—

Long morning visit, from E. Rees. Price Esqr. of Cincinnati, and conversation with him, concerning his imaginary revellations and inspirations— He believes that a universal revolution, in
the Gouvernments of this World, is at this moment in progress.— though as yet, imperceptible, to all but himself— That it commenced, on the equinoxial day, of this month; that all the present Governments, of the earth, are to be overthrown, that of the United States, first, that of Great Britain next, and the rest, in regular succession— In their place, is to arise, a new order of Governments at the head of which, he supposes himself, destined, by revellation to preside, and in which there will be no Department of War, as War is to cease upon earth— He explained to me, in considerable detail, the particulars, of this revolution, and said, he had been subject, of occasional revellations, from the year 1827. having never before, that time, had any religious impressions, of any kind— He illustrated, his imaginary revellations, by numerous references, to Scripture Prophecies, from those of Jacob, in the Book of Genesis, to those of John the Evangelist in the Isle of Patmos; like whom he said, he had been in the Spirit from the Lords Day— He quoted passages from the Books of Isaiah, of Daniel, of Zechariah, of Malacchi, and of the Apoch-lips always naming the Chapter and verse and repeating the prophecies, in the words of the scriptures— His discourse was consistent, in all its details rational and apparently sincere— He said he was alone in the world, that he had no credit in his own Country, not even in his own family, that his wife and children with whom he lived in perfect harmony did not believe him; that of his neighbours, some thought him an imposter, and some a monomaniac, not dishonest in his intentions, reasonable, upon all subjects but one, and on that perfectly insane— All this he knew, but he nevertheless, did believe himself not at all times, but on particular occasions, gifted with inspiration from above. That although no one believed him now, he had no doubt, the time would come, and that not distant, when the truth of what he said, would be universally know and understood— I told him, that I did not believe him an Im
poster and would not call him a monomaniac, but, I believed him labouring under a mental delusion, but, that he had sufficient capacity of reason left, not to take offense, at my candid avowal, of this opinion. He said that far from taking offense, he thanked me for it, and for the kindness with which I had listened to him—and then took his leave— I then went to the House, where I found the Clerk, reading the Journal of yesterday— The Speaker laid before the House a report from the Secretary of War, with a survey of Green Bay, a statistical report from the Treasury Department, and the Naval Register for the year 1846— The resolution offered by McKay for closing debate on the Bill of deficient appropriations at 3. oclock this afternoon, was carried, after an ineffectual attempt to lay it on the table, and another, to postpone its action, till tomorrow— The House immediately took it up, in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Preston King, in the Chair— Then came a long and desultory debate, upon various items in the Bill— Abraham R. McIlvaine of Pennsylvania, objected, to an item of transporting troops into Texas, answered by Douglass of Illinois, much annoyed, at the introduction of Anti Slavery into this, or as he said, all other debates, in this House, Brockenbrough, moved an additional item for the benefit of Florida. Garrett Davis, complained, of the precipitation with which this Bill, was to be hurried through the House, and, that there had been confidential communications, from the Secretary of War, to the Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, which he, declined communicating to the House— Which was expressly admitted by Haralson— Davis pungently replied by pointing out the base subserviency to the Executive, of the Chairman of the Military Committee, in holding secret communications, with the Secretary of War, and refusing to disclose them to the House. And he then turned to Isaac E. Holmes Chairman of the Naval Committee and enquired, if he too
had received any communications from the Secretary of the Navy— Which Holmes very explicitely denied, and declared, that considering himself as the organ of the House, and not of the Executive, he never would receive as Chairman of the Committee of the House, any confidential communication from the head of our Executive Department— Holmes added, that the Committee had called upon the Secretary of the Navy for a statement, of what further sums, for defence, would be required in that Department, and had received a very short reply, asking for ten additional Steam ships— That the Committee considered this quite unsatisfactory, and a call for more specific details, had been referred to estimates, laid before the Senate; that the Committee had received copies of these, which they would lay before the House, as the organ not of the Executive but of the House— George Dromgoole, who was mellow, sported some buffoonery with Davis, and Chipman of Michigan, chattered a few minutes, till 3. o’clock, when the debate was to cease. The Committee then rose— Rathbun moved to reconsider the debate to close the debate at 3. P.M. this day, which the House refused 86. to 96. A Bill from the Senate, about Contracts on water rotted hemp was passed, per saltum McKay moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union again, but without taking the Question, the House adjourned— Evening visits, from Charles Bradbury of Boston, from three English Quakers, by the name of Stacy— Foster, and a third, not recollected, and from a German by the name of Glück employed in the Survey of the Coast— Mr. Bradbury, is an old acquaintance from the time of my residence at Newburyport—as a student at Law, but has been for many years a resident of Boston— He is now here, on an occasional visit of business— The three English Friends, are travellers, upon a tour of observation in the West India Islands and in this Country, upon Anti-Slavery principles— Mr. Glück, is a native of Germany, employed, in the Survey of our Coast—

This morning I finished reading the Book of Ruth, and the stream of my poetical inspiration, ceased for the present, instead of which Mr. E. Rees Price, furnished me yesterday, a supply, of his inspiration about equal in value, to my own— Mrs. Sumner Fairfield, Widow of the late Poet of that name, came to ask me if I had, which I could give to her, a copy of his Poems— But I had it not here— She asked for nothing else— But at the House, a person of the name of Kinsey Dyer, sent and called me from my seat, to say, that he was desirous of an interview with me, at my house, for which I appointed 7. o’clock this evening. The business of the House, commenced, with a call upon Committees for reports— Many of which were made— Andrew Johnson of Tennessee rivalling in the race of popularity, with McConnell of Alabama introduced a Bill for giving way, to every poor man, the head of a family 160 acres, of the public Land without money and without price, which was referred to the Committee of the whole; Archibald Yell of Arkansas, introduced a Bill, to establish a Board of Commissioners, to examine, and decide, on certain Claims, against the United States— A . . . principle, for a Court of Exchequer. Samuel. D. Hubbard, of Connecticut from the Committee on the Militia, reported a Bill, to aid and encourage the States, in raising, organizing, and Officering a legionary Corps. within each State, and for other purposes. Read, committed and five thousand extra copies, of the Bill, and report, ordered to be printed— Orlando B. Ficklin, of Illinois, following “Hand passibus aequis” McConnell of Alabama, and Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, introduced a Bill, to grant 80 Acres of Land to each head of a family, under conditions read and referred to the Committee on Public Lands. Isaac. E. Holmes, Chairman of the Navy Committee sent to the Clerks Table, a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy concerning, the
necessity and manner of increasing the Navy. Mr. Bancroft’s Letter, purports to enclose with it, a copy of a Report, made to the Department, by Commodores Morris, Warrington, Crane, and Shubrick, but no such copy was enclosed. Holmes moved, that the Secretary’s Letter should lie on the Table, and be printed— Which the House refused— Thomas. Butler. King. from the same Naval Committee, undertook to make a verbal report, or statement, referring to a correspondence, between the Committee and the Secretary of the Navy. Objections were made, to the reception of verbal report.— King sent to the Table, this communication from the Navy Department, which after a snarling debate, was not received, but was taken back by Mr. King, who said he would make a report in writing— The House then went into Committee of the whole, Jacob Collamer of Vermont in the Chair, and took up, the Private Calender—reported four or five Bills to the House, passed over 18. others, to which objections were made, and rose, by the vote of a majority not amounting to a quorum— A Question was made, whether the House could receive, a Report from the Committee of the whole, upon which a quorum had not voted; but as the Committee had not reported to the House, that they rose, for want of a quorum; the Speaker, received the report, and put the question on the engrossment, of the Bills reported— Chapman of Alabama, moved to go into Committee of the whole, again— No quorum— Daniel of North Carolina, moved a call of the House— Jenkins of New York, moved to adjourn— Carried by yeas and nays 74 to 65— Mr. Kinsey Dyer came this evening— His business was, to borrow or beg money—from which a dollar relieved me— We had also a visit from Mr. Richard. D. Cutts—

Mr. Kavasales was here this morning, and I told him I had called at the Navy
Department, on the day, he was last here—that I did not see Mr. Bancroft, who was at the President’s in Cabinet Counsel; that I had requested the Chief Clerk, to solicit the Secretary in my name, that Mr. Kavasales, might be ordered to go as Chaplain, with Commodore Reid, who is going out to command a squadron, on the Coast of Africa and in the Mediterranean— And I stated to him, the contents of the Letter from Commodore Reid, to Mr. C. J. Ingersoll, declaring the Commodore’s willingness to take Mr. Kavasales with him as Chaplain— That the Chief Clerk had assured me, that he would make report of my solicitations, to the Secretary, and that I had since received an answer, from Mr. Bancroft that there had already been made, application, for an order to this Station, but that the subject would be duly considered— This was all I was authorized to say, Mr. Kavasales thanked me for my interpolation in his favour, which I do not flatter myself will be successful— I received the evening before last, a Letter from Mrs. F. W. D’Arusmont—heretofore this much known, by the name of Fanny Wright—with it was enclosed, a manuscript Lecture, numbered 15— One of a course, which she proposes to give, at this place, and asks my advice, whether to carry this purpose into execution or not— Madam D’Arusmont, had appeared in the world, with pretensions, as a political and Anti-Religious reformer— And her reputation, had suffered much from her course of life— She said in her Letter, that she proposed to leave this City, this morng. to return, for an indefinite period of time to Europe— I called at her lodgings, at Mrs. Beeler’s between 4 1/2 and 6. Streets, and returned, her manuscript Lecture, declining to advise her, whether to deliver it or not—I believe I had not seen her, for more than 20 years.—and felt the
melancholy impression, upon observing, the ravages, of time, and of evident, adversity, upon her personal appearance— At the House, the reading of the Journal was again dispensed with.— Jacob. S. Yost of Pennsylvania, reported from the Committee on Engraving, a resolution for printing the Maps, transmitted to the House, with the Report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office— Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, made a personal explanation, and the House went into Committee of the whole, and took up the private Callender, upon which sundry Bills, were reported to the House, some with recommendation of their passage, and some to be rejected— The last of these, was the Bill for the relief of the Heirs of Col. William Grayson, against which— Henry. S. Clark, of North Carolina, renewed the objection, which he had withdrawn, when the Bill was last before the Committee— It was rejected, on the Question of engrossment, by yeas and nays, 61. to 65. and the House adjourned—to 12. o’clock on Monday. A resolution had been offered, for meeting hereafter, daily at 11. o’clock A.M. but it was laid on the Table— No evening visitors—

Yesterday morning I commenced reading the 1. Book of Samuel, the last of the ruling Judges of Israel, and this morning, read the account, of the extraordinary capture of the Ark and Covenant, by the Phillistines. At this reading of the Bible, I have been curious, to mark, the Historical incidents, connected with this Ark of the Covenant, containing, the volume of the Law—written by the finger of God, and delivered to Moses on Mount Sinai. In the 25th. Chapter of Exodus, is contained the command of God, to make this Ark, and the 16th. verse, of that Chapter, is in the following words, “And thou shalt put into the Ark, the testimony, which I shall give thee” In the subsequent parts of that Book, are contained the instructions for keeping this Ark, in the Tabernacle
of the Congregation, which was carried, with the Israelites, in their Journeys through the wilderness— In the 31st. Chapter, of Exodus, and the 18th. verse, it is recorded, “That God gave unto Moses, when he had made an end of communing with him, upon Mount Sinai, two Tables of Testimony; Tables of Stone, written with the finger of God”— But while Moses was with God in the Mount, the children of Israel rebelled, and made a molten Calf of gold which they worshipped, as the Gods, which brought them out of the Land of Egypt, upon discovering which, when Moses came down from the Mount, in his indignation, he casts the Tables out of his hands, and brake them, beneath the Mount— In the 34th. Chapter of Exodus, the Lord, commanded Moses, to hew him two Tables of Stone like unto the first, on which he wrote the words, that were in the first Tables— In the 40th. Chapter of Exodus, it is recorded, that in the first month in the 2. year, on the first day of the month, the Tabernacle was reared up, in the Wilderness and Moses, took and put the Testimony into the Ark— In the 18th. Chapter of Joshua, after the conquest of Canaan was completed, it is said, “That the whole Congregation of the Children of Israel assembled together at Shiloah and set up, the Tabernacle of the Congregation there[”]— In the subsequent war, with the Phillistines, as appears by the 4th. Chapter of this first Book of Samuel and the 4th. verse, That the people sent to Shiloah, and brought thence the Ark of the Covenant, between the cherubims and the two Sons of Eli, Hopni and Phinehas and in the battle of the Phillistines it was taken— Carried into the House of Dagon; at Ashdod, successively transferred to Gath.— and thence to Ekron was 7. months in the Country of the Phillistines, then brought to Beth Shemesh and thence to Kirjath Jearim and there remained twenty years, till the days of
David. Its subsequent History, I shall if it please God, notice hereafter— In the Hall of the House of Representatives, I heard the Chaplain of the House Mr. Milburn preach, from 1. Kings 2.2. part of the verse. “Show thyself a man”—it is the beginning of the injunction of David, on his death bed, to his son Solomon, and was commented upon, by the Preacher, with some eloquence, but not to me with much edification— The Hall was well filled, and a Choir from one of the Methodist Churches, sung two Hymns— Isaac Hull Adams dined here, and after dinner at the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, I heard Mr. Matthew Hale Smith preach from James. 1.27—[“]Pure religion, and undefiled, before God, and the Father is this, “To visit the fatherless, and widows, in their affliction and to keep himself unspotted from the world”— James, is the Apostle of good works and not so high authority to the Calvinistic creed, as Paul. Mr. Smith is a Calvinist but believes also, in the inspiration, of James—

A few painful symptoms of rheumatism. I found yesterday, the papers, which had been put in my hands, in Oct 1842, by Alonzo Taft, and took them to the Navy Department, where I saw the Secretary Mr. Bancroft, and left them with him. He placed them in the hands of the Chief Clerk of the Department, and promised immediate attention to them— They had been committed to me, during the recess of Congress— I had brought them with me, at the commencement of the Session then ensuing, and had been mislaid upon a file of papers, from that time to this— An instance of forgetfulness on my part, which has seldom happened, as I have made it a practise, specially to note Papers entrusted to me during the recess of Congress, to be used during the subsequent Session— I lament this delinquency of my memory, and gratefully reflect, that it has
not oftener occured— On the 24th. of this month, I received a Letter dated on the 20th. at Boston, from Alonzo Taft reminding me of the papers which he had entrusted to me in 1842, and enquiring what had become of them— I took his Letter to the Pension Office, the Commissioner of which J. L. Edwards reported to me, that they were not to be found either in that Office or at the Navy Department. I found them now accidentally in searching for other papers—and the discovery of them administered to me. A mingled feeling of mortification and of pleasure— At the House; this was the day, for the call of the states for resolutions and the House went immediately, into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and took up the Bill, making appropriations to supply deficiencies in the appropriation Bills of the last year. The Questions were taken, upon various Amendments, after which the Bill was reported to the House, followed by further desultory debate, and was finally passed by yeas and nays 108. to 38. Abner Lewis of New York moved to re-consider the vote of last Saturday, by which the Bill for the relief of the heirs of Colonel William Grayson was rejected on the question of engrossment— The motion was laid over for consideration— The House, at the motion of George. C. Dromgoole, went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Joseph Johnson, in the Chair, and took up the Sub-Treasury Bill so-called.— The Bill was read through, after several motions, to supercede, the rule requiring that it should be so read, and then taken up by sections— A debate upon it was commenced, by Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, continued, by William W. Wick, of the same State. Shelton F. Leake of Virginia and John. S. Chipman of Michigan—who had spoken only about five minutes, when a quarter to five the Committee rose, and the House adjourned. No evening visitors—

An almost sleepless night and much of the morning wasted, in writing verses— Mr. Otis Drury of Boston, came, to claim my assistance in a claim, which he has upon the Government— Some weeks since, there were shipped, by a Quarter Master here, in the Schooner Joy, belonging to Mr. Drury, thirteen pieces of Canon, to be transported to Pensacola, for this Government— On the 2d. of this month, the vessal was stranded on Cran Island near Norfolk, Virginia, and there remains, with the Canons, still on board— Mr. Drury, has been to Norfolk, and comes here, to claim an average, upon the loss, for the proportion, of the value of the guns, and for the charges of recovering them, and transporting them, to Pensacola, according to the original Contract— I went with Mr. Drury, and introduced him to the Secretary of War, Marcy, and to the Quarter Master General, Jesup; to them he stated his claim, and I left him, to agree with them, upon the measures to be pursued, for the fulfilment, of this contract with the Government, after which, I took him to his lodgings, at Coleman’s Hotel; and proceeded to the Capitol, where I found the House in session— Alex. D. Simms, of South Carolina, had moved a resolution, that the daily hour of adjournment, of the House, should hereafter be, to 11. o’clock, A.M. until other was ordered. Winthrop objected— Simms moved, a suspension of the rules— Carried by yeas and nays 105. to 52. and the resolution was adopted— The Speaker, laid before the House, a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury stating, the withdrawal, of the deposit of Public monies, from sundry Banks and individuals, and the Amount, of the present deposits in many others 34. in number— Dromgoole, moved a resolution, to close the debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the union on the sub-Treasury Bill next Thursday, at 1. o’clock— Sundry amendments
were proposed and rejected, and the resolution was adopted The House immediately went into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, Joseph Johnson in the Chair and took up the Bill— Chipman of Michigan concluded the Speech which he yesterday commenced, in support of it— Joseph. R. Ingersoll followed for an hour against it and Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina replied to him— Charles. J. Ingersoll, who had offered an Amendment to the Bill with two or three preliminary whereas’s made a random Speech of an hour, in support of them—and Milton Brown, in less than an hour demolished them all; demonstrating the glaring blunders of which they were composed— John. H. McHenry of Kentucky took the floor, the Committee rose and the House adjourned to 11. o’clock tomorrow morning— My wife dined abroad, at Mr. Frye’s We had evening visits from Mr. Healy, Dubourjal, and Mr. John Connell—
